message_1: "A particle with a lifetime of 5 microseconds and a rest mass of 1.5 GeV/c^2 travels at a speed of 0.8c. Calculate the distance traveled by the particle before it decays."
message_2:
To solve this problem, we need to use the concept of time dilation in special relativity. Time dilation states that the time experienced by a moving object (proper time) is shorter than the time experienced by an observer at rest (coordinate time).

The formula for time dilation is:

Δt = Δτ / √(1 - v^2/c^2)

where Δt is the coordinate time, Δτ is the proper time, v is the velocity of the moving object, and c is the speed of light.

Given the lifetime of the particle (proper time) is 5 microseconds and its speed is 0.8c, we can calculate the coordinate time (Δt) experienced by an observer at rest:

Δt = (5 x 10^-6 s) / √(1 - (0.8c)^2/c^2)
Δt = (5 x 10^-6 s) / √(1 - 0.64)
Δt = (5 x 10^-6 s) / √(0.36)
Δt = (5 x 10^-6 s) / 0.6
Δt ≈ 8.33 x 10^-6 s

Now that we have the coordinate time, we can calculate the distance traveled by the particle before it decays:

distance = speed × time
distance = 0.8c × 8.33 x 10^-6 s

Since c = 3 x 10^8 m/s, we can substitute this value into the equation:

distance = 0.8 × (3 x 10^8 m/s) × 8.33 x 10^-6 s
distance ≈ 2 x 10^8 m/s × 8.33 x 10^-6 s
distance ≈ 1.666 x 10^8 m × 8.33 x 10^-6
distance ≈ 1.387 x 10^3 m

So, the particle travels approximately 1,387 meters before it decays.
